  14. (**************************************************************************)

  16. (** Deferred computations. *)

  18. ‌type 'a t = 'a CamlinternalLazy.t
  19. (** A value of type ['a Lazy.t] is a deferred computation, called a suspension,
  20.     that has a result of type ['a]. The special expression syntax [lazy (expr)]
  21.     makes a suspension of the computation of [expr], without computing
  22.     [expr] itself yet. "Forcing" the suspension will then compute [expr] and
  23.     return its result. Matching a suspension with the special pattern syntax
  24.     [lazy(pattern)] also computes the underlying expression and tries to bind
  25.     it to [pattern]:

  27.     {[
  28.       let lazy_option_map f x =
  29.       match x with
  30.       | lazy (Some x) -> Some (Lazy.force f x)
  31.       | _ -> None
  32.     ]}

  34.     Note: If lazy patterns appear in multiple cases in a pattern-matching, lazy
  35.     expressions may be forced even outside of the case ultimately selected by
  36.     the pattern matching. In the example above, the suspension [x] is always
  37.     computed.

  39.     Note: [lazy_t] is the built-in type constructor used by the compiler for the
  40.     [lazy] keyword.  You should not use it directly.  Always use [Lazy.t]
  41.     instead.

  43.     Note: [Lazy.force] is not concurrency-safe. If you use this module with
  44.     multiple fibers, systhreads or domains, then you will need to add some
  45.     locks. The module however ensures memory-safety, and hence, concurrently
  46.     accessing this module will not lead to a crash but the behaviour is
  47.     unspecified.

  49.     Note: if the program is compiled with the [-rectypes] option,
  50.     ill-founded recursive definitions of the form [let rec x = lazy x]
  51.     or [let rec x = lazy(lazy(...(lazy x)))] are accepted by the type-checker
  52.     and lead, when forced, to ill-formed values that trigger infinite
  53.     loops in the garbage collector and other parts of the run-time system.
  54.     Without the [-rectypes] option, such ill-founded recursive definitions
  55.     are rejected by the type-checker.
  56. *)


  59. exception Undefined
  60. (** Raised when forcing a suspension concurrently from multiple fibers,
  61.     systhreads or domains, or when the suspension tries to force itself
  62.     recursively.
  63. *)

  65. external force : 'a t -> 'a = "%lazy_force"
  66. (** [force x] forces the suspension [x] and returns its result. If [x] has
  67.     already been forced, [Lazy.force x] returns the same value again without
  68.     recomputing it.  If it raised an exception, the same exception is raised
  69.     again.

  71.     @raise Undefined (see {!Undefined}).
  72. *)

  74. (** {1 Iterators} *)

  76. ‌val map : ('a -> 'b) -> 'a t -> 'b t
  77. (** [map f x] returns a suspension that, when forced,
  78.     forces [x] and applies [f] to its value.

  80.     It is equivalent to [lazy (f (Lazy.force x))].

  82.     @since 4.13
  83. *)

  85. (** {1 Reasoning on already-forced suspensions} *)

  87. ‌val is_val : 'a t -> bool
  88. (** [is_val x] returns [true] if [x] has already been forced and
  89.     did not raise an exception.
  90.     @since 4.00 *)

  92. ‌val from_val : 'a -> 'a t
  93. (** [from_val v] evaluates [v] first (as any function would) and returns
  94.     an already-forced suspension of its result.
  95.     It is the same as [let x = v in lazy x], but uses dynamic tests
  96.     to optimize suspension creation in some cases.
  97.     @since 4.00 *)

  99. ‌val map_val : ('a -> 'b) -> 'a t -> 'b t
  100. (** [map_val f x] applies [f] directly if [x] is already forced,
  101.    otherwise it behaves as [map f x].

  103.    When [x] is already forced, this behavior saves the construction of
  104.    a suspension, but on the other hand it performs more work eagerly
  105.    that may not be useful if you never force the function result.

  107.    If [f] raises an exception, it will be raised immediately when
  108.    [is_val x], or raised only when forcing the thunk otherwise.

  110.    If [map_val f x] does not raise an exception, then
  111.    [is_val (map_val f x)] is equal to [is_val x].

  113.     @since 4.13 *)


  116. (** {1 Advanced}

  118.    The following definitions are for advanced uses only; they require
  119.    familiary with the lazy compilation scheme to be used appropriately. *)

  121. ‌val from_fun : (unit -> 'a) -> 'a t
  122. (** [from_fun f] is the same as [lazy (f ())] but slightly more efficient.

  124.     It should only be used if the function [f] is already defined.
  125.     In particular it is always less efficient to write
  126.     [from_fun (fun () -> expr)] than [lazy expr].

  128.     @since 4.00 *)

  130. ‌val force_val : 'a t -> 'a
  131. (** [force_val x] forces the suspension [x] and returns its result.  If [x]
  132.     has already been forced, [force_val x] returns the same value again
  133.     without recomputing it.

  135.     If the computation of [x] raises an exception, it is unspecified
  136.     whether [force_val x] raises the same exception or {!Undefined}.
  137.     @raise Undefined if the forcing of [x] tries to force [x] itself
  138.     recursively.

  140.     @raise Undefined (see {!Undefined}).
  141. *)
